tail: JKP. One who is afraid should not go; the one who climbs in the tree let that one eat. Said when going hunting or fishing. 4634. Achanikaye kwenye mpini hafi njaa. EM.8.1. The person who gets blisters from the hoe-handle will not die of hunger. A diligent worker will reap the fruits of his industry. 4635. Ah! Haifai maishani. KER. Shouts of disgust are useless in life
RSP.20. The person who goes to the forest will come back with firewood.
SAM. 2.10. One who complains much does little. Not only does that person do little, but also prevents others from achieving.

RECH.444; SACL. 757; V. 129; T.597; KS, lala. So and So sleeps like a pono [fish]. Is lazy. V. Students are afraid of eating the pono, because it would make them lazy or stupid. V., pono. Umekula pono? Have you eaten the pono? Are you sleepy? Lazy? Pono: a kind of sluggish fish that lives among the coral.
ED.78. So and So sleeps like a puff adder.
. V.130. A person as tall as the devil.
KS, mlingoti. Someone tall like a (ship's) mast.
. KS,unju. Tall like Unju. Unju: an extremely tall person.
REK. One who expects to live for free will live in poverty.

quote: Avunjaye nazi ni lazima ale tui yake.
tail: MEM.110. The one who cracks the coconut should consume the cream. The person who does the hard work should enjoy the fruits of that work. MEM.
KB.30; TS 40,12. That person can change a garbage dump into wealth. KB. By continual effort the poor can become rich. But TS puts it under vanity: someone is bragging.

quote: Biashara ya pembe hapana cha kuambulia.
tail: KA. At the ivory market there is no profit. The ivory market is expensive. Used when people waste time in looking and admiring. Kuambulia or faida: profit.

JKP. For nothing, for nothing, never satisfies. "A beggar is never satisfied. Once you give something away, the receiver will expect the same gift again." JKP. Doing work without remuneration does not satisfy.
NGU. A human being must make an effort.
SAM.5.5. A valley's beginning is a hill. Before obtaining a state of well-being, we must work for it: Climbing up before we can go down. SAM.
KB.33. A little, but earned, is the best.

quote: Bora  kidogo kwa haki kuliko mali  nyingi kwa wovu.
tail: KB.33. The little acquired honestly is better than much but ill acquired.
L. p.ll2. A thing for nothing is not obtainable.

mwema na mwovu, hawajulikani. mwenye nia mbovu, ingia kisimani. JKP #603. Dig, dig with perseverance The good and the wicked cannot be distinguished Anyone with a bad intention falls in this well. "A well-diggers' song." JKP.

quote: Fumbe na mleli wake, haulali ndora.
tail: SACL. 230; JKP. The widow bird with its long tail never sleeps. This is used as an invitation to workers to work harder. "Be active, for the black bird is a memento of dying, since it is associated with the grave". JKP. Fumbe or fumbwe: a wydah, a sparrow with a long tai1. Mleli: feather, for tail. Ndora: name of a field.
JKP. A craftsman is not hungry. "A skilled worker will always find work". JKP.

quote: Fundi mbaya huteta na ala zake.
tail: JK.144. The bad craftsman quarrels with the tools. Cf. #1990.
REK. The car does not move the owner. Because one has a car it does not absolve the owner from making efforts to be accepted in society.
NGU. Nothing is free.

quote: Hakuna kitu kigumu kwa mtu mwenye bidii.
tail: NGU. Nothing is hard for an energetic person.
MARA 2; KA. Big steps shortens a walk. Used to encourage effort.

quote: Heri kwenda bure kama kukaa bure.
tail: JKP. It is better to go in vain than to stay in vain. "You regret more what you did not do than what you did." JKP. Cf.#1994; #1999; #2024.
RSP.70. The donkey works all his life, [and only] the vultures like it [after its death]. RSP.
JK.118. One cuts oneself, to put oneself together. JK. You almost destroy oneself working, then you have to restore your strength and start again. JK.
EM i8. The devil oppresses the lazy. The devil looks for people who have plenty of idle time. EM.

quote: Imani hufa kwa sumu ya ujira mbaya.
tail: EM I4. Trust dies because bad pay poisons it Trust needs a good satisfying reponse. EM.
NGU. Bow down so that you may get it. Refers to effort in order to obtain what you want and need. But of course can also be used as "Courtesy opens all doors". Cf. #159.
NGU. A person's sweat is not eaten. Do not exploit or depend on another's work. Kula jasho la mwenzako: to depend on the work of another. (idiom).
EM j4. God does not ignore a person's sweat. Work is rewarded.
REK. The hoe in the soil [brings] health to the body. Work brings food on the table.
AL,ongoza; AL 1563. The hoe does not lead the farmer. The inferior (hoe) must not give orders to the higher up.
AL 164. With the hoe in the hand, there will be food to eat. Cf.#1971f.
NGU. Scratch yourself where you can reach. Do your own scratching. Help yourself. Do what you can.
V.,jogoo. The rooster is the village's clock.
JKP. Sit near [your own] rope [of the main sail] and hold it in your hand. "Don't be a back-seat driver, stick to your job." JKP. Damani or demani: rope of mainsail.
JKP. Embraze the coconut tree and climb it, start work. "Many Swahili workers used to be employed as coconut pickers. They were paid by the number of trees they had climbed." JKP.
NGU. Work without play does not go well. Mix work with leisure and you will never go mad (Russian proverb).

JKP. The work will not progress if one does not know the rules [for the initiated]. The work cannot be satisfactory until you are accepted and know all the tricks. "A specialized knowledge for every job." JKP. Cf.#1258A.

quote: Kazi isiyo faida kutenda si ada.
tail: A.206; T.132. Work without profit, it is not fit for reward. Uselessness is damaging. V.

quote: Kazi,  isiyokuwa na manufaa, kutenda si ada.
tail: V.103. Useless work is worthless.

quote: Kazi isiyo  kipimo mwishowe watu hutetana.
tail: A.206; T.133; L.110; SAM.9.4; KB.91. Work that has no measure, at the end of it people quarrel. Do not overburden a fellow human being. SAM. Cf. #2019, #1984.
NGU. Work must be done.

A.202; T.134; J, wi; MARA.24; SACL..338; V.,kazi; F.14.7, kazi mbaya; KB.92; STEERE, p.192; KS, kazi. Bad work is better than good play. A laborious work cannot be compared with the attraction of play: one has profit, the other leads to starvation. Sacl. Poor-at-work is better than good-at-games. Hurry the crossing, p.117. A take-off: Kazi mbili si mchezo mwema. NGU. Working two jobs is not nice play.
REK. Hard work give it to the Almighty. Do not do the impossible.
MA.158. Work is a treasure. Work is a source of prosperity and happiness.
EM k4. Work is income. "In order to gain something you must work for it. To desire a thing without work is to fall into the Devil's trap." EM.
SEMI.12. Work for the little pot on the stove. To work for food or daily need only, not for a salary.
KS,meko. To work just for food.
KS,msira. Work for a miser does not pay. Sira: dreg, leftover pulp.

quote: Kazi ya  shikazi, niwachia kazi!  Kazi ya msira huisira-sira.
tail: T.135; SACL. 597. Work for money, leave that to me. The work for a miser I usually scamp. Msira for bahili: miser. Shikazi: old word for dollar.
NGU. All work is useful.

quote: Kibarua  hulima juani, tajiri hulia kivulini.
tail: EM k6. A day-worker cultivates in the sun, the master eats in the shade. One toils, the other munches.
JKP. That which exposes you [to danger] is your stomach. "The stomach commands the Swahili to go out on dangerous journeys to earn their living." JKP. Ponda: pound to pieces, crush.
AL,kunga. Every craft has its own techniques.
NGU. All sweet things [pleasant happenings] have been prepared.
NGU. Everything that shines has been brushed.
ZO p.253. Everything has its beginnings Chimbuko, also, mwanzo, asili, chanzo: a beginning. Cf. # 523.
T.637. Everything has its time [or measure].
JKP. Every drum has its own dance. "Every work has its own way of being performed. No two works are similar" JKP.

quote: Kilimia  kikizama kwa jua huzuka kwa mvua; kikizama kwa mvua huzuka kwa jua.
tail: V.,kilimia; KA., zama; T.150; KS, zama. When the Pleiades set in sun [sunny weather] they rise in rain; when they set in rain they rise in sun. Kilimia: the Pleiades or the seven sisters, probably from kulima, to cultivate: by which to start cultivating.
KS,kilimo. Cultivate till you drop. The idiom Kufa na kupona: dying and getting better, means to try something by all means, to give everything you have. Cf #548.

KA. A worn out hoe did more hoeing than a whole one. Don't despise a nobody. Sometimes they are or were more useful than 'important' people. Kisilima or kiserema or kisagalima: an old worn out hoe, of which only a part is remaining and no good for farming anymore.
REK. The bed is like a brother/sister.
ZO 254. As it is tapped so it will be drunk. Cf #2000.

quote: Kiuno  kiteke kinang'aa; hakikai nyumba moja na njamaa.
tail: FSM.77. The soft waist that shines with perspiration does not dwell in the same house as hunger. FSM. Used in the teaching of girls' initiation. Njamaa stands for njaa: hunger. Provides the explanation of FSM.
NGU. A beautiful thing is made. Cf. #2020.
NGU. If the hat fits wear it. Accept a job you like and can fulfill; accept also the praise or blame earned.

quote: Kozi mwana  mandanda, kulala na njaa kupenda.
tail: F.16.37; SACL. 443; KS,kozi. The goshawk is a skilled hunter; if it sleeps hungry, it is its own fault.
F.17.38; AL 1452; KA; NGU. One ordering farm work gets only clearing of undergrowth. If you leave your work to others, it will not be done properly.

T. 166. Does sending an order imply ability? Kufyekeza from kufyeka: to make a clearing in the forest to sweep away, and therefore sometimes means: to destroy. Thus a translation could be: To give orders is to destroy.
JKP. To order is not the same as to get the job done. To order a job does not mean that it will be done right.
KS, ngoma. Play the drum for free. Do something without profit.

quote: Kufadhiliwa ni kubaya, akufadhiliye ni bwana wako.
tail: MARA 2. Receiving favors is bad, the one who gives them is your master. Cf. # 1967.
EM k26. Living is like riding a bicycle. "If you ride a bicycle you must pedal if you want to move. If you don't pedal, you will fall off. To live is to work hard. The alternative is death." EM.
F.18.52; MARA 3; KA. Eating is sweet, hoeing is weariness. Mavune or machovu: stiffness in the joints, fatigue, weariness. Cf. #293; #585.
NS.2. Eating is the earnings of work.

quote: Kula  uhondo kwataka matendo, asiye na matendo hula uvundo.
tail: KA. In order to eat generously, deeds are needed; without working one eats bad smelling food. In order to live in peace, a person must work hard, if he doesn't he'll live a life of trouble. Uhondo: a big feast, generous entertainment. Uvundo: a bad smell, stink. From -vunda: be high. Of meat which has been laid by, so that it is smelling somewhat but is still fit to be eaten.
RSP.18. Farm work needs measure. You have to know your needs and if you have people working your land, you must arrange payment. Cf. #1974.

quote: Kulima kwataka jembe na mikono ya kunyoka.
tail: JKP. Field work requires a hoe and the stretching of the arms

quote: Kulima  pekee ni kujihiliki; mawe na manyasi hayakusanyiki.
tail: JKP. Cultivating alone is suicide; stones and weeds cannot be raked together. Jihiliki: self destruction.

quote: Kulima  polepole, kulima na kidole, utalala nacho.
tail: AL 377. If you are a lazy farmer, doing work with one finger, you will sleep with that finger [in your mouth]. You'll be sorry. If you work without spirit, you invite penury. AL.

quote: Kumpatia  mlimaji chakula, mchezaji atapeleka vyote.
tail: AL 1238; AL, peleka. Giving food to the farmer,the dancer will take it all. When a working person gets something, it is often taken away by a lazy person.

quote: Kuna ufundi pia katika kuburura rukwama.
tail: SAM.10. 17; MM. There is craftsmanship even in dragging along the heavy center pole supporting the roof of a house. MM.
AL 172; AL, kitoweo. The coming and going of the mouse has provided it with food.

quote: Kutema  kuni ku bora kuliko kunyosha mkono kwa kiumbe.
tail: MA.l91. Cutting [firewood] is better than putting the hand out to someone [for alms]. Cf# 1986. Kutenda kazi twatenda, lakini bamba ni gumu. T.197. [As for] doing the work, we do [it], but the object is hard. Cf. #420.

quote: Kutwanga nisile unga, nazuia mchi wangu.
person: I deny my pestle. No work without profit.
tail: AL 1264. Grinding the grain and not being allowed to eat the flour, I deny my pestle. No work without profit.

quote: Kuvua  samaki mwungwana si tua kwa wenye akili.
tail: MA.234. For an intelligent person fishing is not a disgrace. Fishing is a degrading job to some people. Here we understand that this should not be so for it is better to fish than to beg or steal.

quote: Kuvunjika  kwa mwiko si mwisho wa kusonga ugali.
tail: AL 987, AL,mwiko. If the wooden spatula breaks it is not the end of stiring porridge. If a spouse dies, she is replaced; procreation has to go on. Cf. #1987.

quote: Kuzima  koleo si mwisho wa uhunzi.
tail: J.; F.19.63; CM.51; KB.135; MARA 3; KA; T.204; SACL. 1011. Cooling the tongs is not the end of forging. To know how to cool the tongs is not all the work of forging. KB; SACL. Giving up a bad habit is not a warranty for giving up that habit for ever. MARA.
NS.l. First work, then wages.
KA. Even just loitering is better than sitting doing nothing. Cf. #1994.
MARA 3; SM. Attend to what must be done. There is no excuse.
KB.159. Wind-swept clouds don't give rain. Much ado about nothing.

CM.44; F.23.28; SWA.15; B.2.57; L.45; MARA.39; JKP; KS,jembe. One who "picks" his hoe is not a real farmer. A bad workman blames his tools. F. A good fighter can use any type of weapon. SWA. JKP has a special insight: "Our fate is determined by others and by random events. E.g. the girl's father selects a bridegroom for her." Cf. #1997.

quote: Mchezea  chuma huchuma, kama hakuchuma tumbo hunguruma.
tail: TAA 131. The person who lets the hoe dance will harvest; if there is no harvest that person's stomach will grumble. Chuma: (n.) iron, hoe, etc. Chuma: (v.) to harvest, to earn.

quote: 4726   mchimba kaburi ana faida, kefu mranda mbao.
tail: KB.174; AL 170. The grave-digger makes a living, so much the more the wood planer in making the coffin. There is no low craft, only low people. KB. Cf. #1985.
CM.44; T.330; SACL. 334; F.24.39; A.73; V.43; KB.173. A well-digger is not refused water.
RSP. 37. One does not refuse water to the child of the well-digger.
F.25.45; KA. A person who makes a living in the sun, eats in the shade. Rest is sweet after overcoming hard work.
AL 166. A hawker sleeps without comfort, but eats well. Being away from home, one'll sleep where possible. Cf. #1979A; #1982; #1983; #1988.

quote: Mgaagaa na  upwa hali wali mtupu.
tail: J.,gaagaa; T.59.259; B.3.2; MARA 3; KA; AL 1706. One who haunts the shore does not eat plain rice. Always plcking up something. The fishermen usually give him a fish. It is useful to frequent people that can be or are useful to you.

quote: Mgaagaa  wa mpwa hali vyakula vikavu.
tail: F.25.54; AL 1239. A lazy person with a nephew does not eat dry food. Sends his nephew to get what is needed. F. Upwa: low tide. Mpwa: nephew. Mgaagaa: an idler, restless person, beachcomber; rolling stone. J.

quote: Mtafutaji  wa mpwa hali wali mtupu.
tail: KA. One who looks up a nephew does not eat dry rice.
KA. A restless child does not eat plain polenta.
NGU. One who cares for the stomach must sweat for it.
NGU. They who sit on their hoe are not farmers.
FSM.117. The track made by the hoe does not tell a lie. The meaning is that work is rewarding.

quote: Mkokoto wa jembe si bure yao.
tail: KA; AL 461. The dragging of the hoe is not worthless. If a farmer drags his hoe being tired after work, it is understood that there is nothing shameful about it. Said to somebody who looks down on a dirty, sweating worker. Si bure yao: is not useless, is not worthless, is valuable.

quote: Mkoba wa  mwindaji umevimba; ukikosa nyama, haukosi uyoga.
tail: KB.235; AL 1848. A hunter's bag is full; even if it does not contain meat, it contains at least mushrooms. Cf. #1994, #1960.
JK.128. The farmer does not eat alone. Cf. #1998.
JK.144; NGU. The lazy farmer blames his tools. Cf. #1990.

quote: Mkulima ni  mmoja, walaji ni wengi.
tail: T.273; F.27.77; JK.129; KB.189; SACL. 569; MARA 3. The farmer is one, those who eat are many. Many enjoy the fruits of his work. A farmer has many dependents. JK. Richness attracts many profiteers. KB. A good deed profits many others too. MARA. Cf. #1996.
RSP.115. The sleeper in the shade, what will that person eat?
NGU. Break it up for the cat, don't you have a hand? Telling people what to do, but doing nothing oneself.
F.29.93; J; B.1.71; MEM.94; V.2; NS.4; KB.195; SACL. 717; MARA 3. One who plants in a disorderly fashion will eat likewise. As you sow, so shall you reap.

MARA 2; KA. If you farm 'What's enough for me," you will harvest "What is finished." If you farm a small piece of land only, you'll have a small harvest. To encourage people to work well. Pantosha for pananitosha: what is enough for me. Pankwisha for pamekwisha: what's finished. Cf. #2006.

quote: Mpenda cha bure, hufa kidole mdomoni.
tail: REK. One who loves free things dies with the finger in the mouth. Kidole mdomoni: the finger in the mouth of frustration and regret.
NS.3. One who loves to eat is lazy. Said during the rainy season when often the whole day is spent in the field.

quote: Mpewa chakula na watu hana uso.
tail: MA.12. One who is given food by people has no face. This is said of people who depend on others for their living. People who do not work to earn their daily bread are considered faceless, i.e., they cannot enjoy their rights and cannot express their opinion lest they lose the favor of their benefactors.

quote: Mpigwa chini na jembe huinuwa na lilo koongo.
tail: T.308a. One who is brought to the ground by the hoe is lifted up by that same delving. One who is bent down working the land, will rise to a good life. Koongo: a hole dibbled or dug with a hoe for planting seeds.
JK.ll9. A fool has no work. JK. Mpuzi: a person who likes talking and most of the time the talk is useless. Hence a person who has time for such talk implies that there is no work to be done. MM.
NGU. Being tossed about is the way the dug-out canoe moves. Msukosuko: rolling, pitching.

quote: Mtama ni muwi na wapishi nao.
tail: T.318; JK.144; AL 1400. If the millet dish is bad, the cooks are no good. If something goes wrong others are blamed.

quote: Mchele  ni mui na wapishi nao.
tail: KS,mchele. Rice is bad and so are the cooks. Cf. #1969, #1997.
REK. A restless child stays without going to the toilet, Not taking time to go. Cf. # 1994.
T.333a; V.2; SACL. 728. What a person sows will be reaped. Cf. #358, #2000.

quote: Mtu asiwe nawara, uvivu huleta hasara.
tail: JKP. A person should not be idle, laziness causes damage.
KB.203. One cannot feed on wind. You cannot live on air. One does not live on love and fresh water. KB.
SAM.17.30. Human beings consume their strength. You should make use of your talents to support yourself, and not be dependent on the work of others.
F.32.126; L.67; Mulika, p.l0; MARA.51; H.81; ED. 44; AL,maskini. One who relies on relatives will die poor. Cf. #2002.
JK.145 A lazy person does not sow up a small wound. That person neglects doing small repairs, does not take care of property or health. Cf. #1746.
ED.57; JK.120, hutafuna, AL.376. A lazy person chews empty coconut-shells. Gaguna or tafuna: to chew. Fuvu: empty shell; husk

quote: Mvivu  hutumaini kupata hapati; mwenye bidii hunenepa.
tail: NGU. The lazy person hopes to get it and does not; the hard worker grows fat.
ED.50. A fisherman unable to fish makes a fishing line. One can always do something useful. ED. Cf. #394.
KS.,mtukutu. An active child does not eat dry food. Mtukutu: restless, active

quote: Mwanamume  ni kazi, bila kazi hajaliwi, mpuzi hafanyi kazi.
tail: JKP. Being a man is hard work, without work he is not respected, a fool does not work.

quote: Mwanzo ni kuchuma, kisha ni kusona.
tail: JKP. First harvest, then rest. Kusona: to rest in fresh air.

quote: Mwenda  bure si mkaa bure; huenda akaokota.
tail: AL 171. A loafer is better than an idler; usually a loafer finds something useful. Activity is better than doing nothing.
JK.126. A hunchback cannot lie down on the back. A poor person can never stop working and never rest. JK. Cf. #1193.
AL 173. The one who made you walk at night, you'll praise in the morning. All effort, even irksome, is remunerated.

quote: Mzigo huwa mzito karibu ya nyumbani.
tail: NGU. A load gets heavy approaching home.

JK.233; AL 594. I kill myself for rice: it has already an owner. I work myself to the core cultivating rice, it is mine. Don't attribute to yourself what another has earned. To work for nothing. AL. Cf, # 2015.
KB.234; AL, kanda. I kill myself for a handful of rice.

quote: Nafia pumba la  maganda, mchele kwa belgika.
tail: Maniema dialect. AL 595. I kill myself for a ball of husks, while the rice goes to Belgika. Belgika: a Belgian agricultural company. Maganda for ng'anda:a handful. Cf #2014.

quote: Ndimu  mpaka uikamue, ndipo utaona maji yake.
tail: AL 143. It's not until you squeeze the lemon, that you'll see its juice.
TAA 17. Go away from your relative, do not live together. Do not be dependent on your relative, you'll get on each others' nerves. Be self supporting. Cf #954. # 2009.
NGU. It is easier to destroy than to build up.
REK. I'll do it, I'll do it, is negligence. Uzembe: slackness, idleness, indifference.

quote: Nyuki  anaunda asali, bungo anaunda udongo.
tail: KS,bungo. A bee works with honey, a mason wasp works with clay.
MARA 2. Begging and begging brings abjection.
Swahili II:88. A donkey does not go unless you beat it. Said of stubborn children, etc.
JK.137. A donkey does not move unless a stick is used.

quote: Rahisi kufahamu la kufanya kuliko kulifanya.
tail: EM r8. It is easier to know what to do than to do it.
NGU. No honor comes to a useless person. Goigoi: lazy, weak person.
JK.126. B1ack day, white money. Hard work, good pay. JK.
NGU. We all would be lazy, if only we could.
AL,matongo; AL 169. A deserted village, where an active person was living, does not lack a pawpaw tree. Good work produces fruit Tongo or mahame: deserted village.
T.507. We are a-cultivating. A greeting during cultivation time. The rejoinder is: ni kazini, I too am busy. Ndimani from lima: farming. n + l = nd.

quote: Ukimpa mtu kazi pataneni na ujira.
tail: A.120, T.523. If you give a person work [first] agree upon the wages.
SAM.3.14. One who gives work to a person should agree upon wages. Cf. #1974.

F.46.8; JK.141; H.104. When you see them float, [remember] they have been built. JK. Much knowledge and effort went into making the boats. JK. Everything has a cause. A complete article must have gone though various stages in its creation.
B.3.21. They float, they have been made.
RECH.579. If you see [a boat] that floats, it has been created. Things have to be done well and must not be taken for granted. Cf. #1979d.

quote: Ukitaka  chakula wakati wa masika, ujikaze.
tail: TS 137/28. If you want food during the raining season, start working Masika is the time to cultivate and it is when most from the last harvest has been consumed.

EM u11. If you want to eat fish, you must become wet (or, you must fish). When you are fishing you must enter the water. About taking the proper means. Loa: take something out of water. KS. Lowa: get wet. J. Cf. #159.
NGU. If you count on your neighbor, you'll die a pauper.
. NGU. If you put your hope in your neighbor, you'll become poor.
A.140; J.,kaa; T.528; SAM..24.8: mkaazi; KB.310. If you are going to stay in a place, build a house. Show your intentions clearly from the beginning.

quote: Ukiwa mkazi  jenga; ukosefu wa mwenenzi si wa kazi milele.
tail: AL, enda. If you are going to stay in one place, build; mistakes of someone who is passing by are not comparable to those who reside for ever.

quote: Ulichopanda ule, hata hukusugua mkono wake.
tail: AL 162. Eat what you planted, even if you have not scrubbed your hand. Your good right to enjoy the fruit of your labor in any circumstances.
RSP.98. The tongue makes no profit. Talking is of no use. JK.

F.28,23; KS.,jeta; AL 367. Have you become a jeta, that you are not able to move. A lazy person who does not move to get things needed, but asks to be given them, though the things may be quite near. "From the habit that the small Indian shopkeeper has of squatting in his shop at ease, and asking his customers to reach him things not immediately within his reach." J. Jeta: a snail of the sea that always sits on a rock.
AL 365. You think about sleeping while dawn is here. The lazy person follows an abnormal life style. AL.
NGU. When you scratch your scabies, you enjoy it. The joy of doing things.

CM.50; J.,pika; V.145; KB.323; SACL. 966; AL, kuni. Cooking means firewood. If you want the end, you must take the means. Much work is involved in collecting firewood. Often preparation takes more time than the thing itself. Without bait it's hard fishing. V.
EM u31. Even the most clever child cannot escape sleep. Sleep cannot be avoided. Man's weakness.
EM u32 Sleep is the wealth of the poor. The poor have no possessions. Sleep temporarily removes them from pressing needs of life. EM.
EM u33. Sleep is not wealth. Sleep does not bring wealth.

quote: Usione mkono wa salamu ukazidisha hadi begani.
tail: REK. Don't expect a welcoming hand while you add even more on your shoulder. Of people who are workaholics.
KS,kupe. Don't be a parasite, be self-supporting. A strong, healthy person who does not work, but leans upon others for a living. KS. Kupe: a tick; a parasite.
AL,raha. Don't be like a corpse, a lover of comfort.
AL 597. When I work on the land you'll pass me by, but not when I eat.
KS,vuna. You'll harvest what you sow.
J.,rithi, AL.,rithi. Laziness engenders poverty.
JK.118. Laziness causes poverty. Cf. #ll27.
T.571. September-rains, 'tis in crowds (the people go). The people are eager to be about their cultivation. Kifulifuli probably from kufulia: to hasten on with the work before the rain stops.

quote: Ukisikia vuli  yaja, kazi za shamba hakonde huzudi
tail: . Upon hearing that the rains are near, the work of clearing the fields increases. MM.
EM v4. Break the coconut to get the copra. If you want a good thing you must work for it. It is not easy to get a valuable thing. EM.
RSP.30. If you want to improve your standards, you must leave your bed. Kupanda: to rise or climb up, and also to plant crops.
T.585. Those who work do not fail to have a reason [or need].

quote: Waungwana huchumia juani na kulia kivulini.
tail: REK. Good men harvest in the heat of the sun and eat in the shade. They work hard for a living.
